data.text: Some important cities
data.text1: Pakistan does not have many large cities.
data.text: Islamabad, the capital of Pakistan, is a new, planned city located at the base of the Margalla Hills.
Islamabad is the seat of the government.
Islamabad has a population of about 9 00 000.
Shah Faisal Mosque, one of the largest mosques in the world, is located in Islamabad.
The Supreme Court, the Secretariat, and the Quaid-e-Azam University are some well-known buildings in Islamabad.
Karachi is the largest city of Pakistan and was the capital of Pakistan before 1959.
Karachi grew from a small village to a major port due to the natural harbour at Keamari.
In the 19<font face="GG Superscript">th</font> century, the British made major developments to the city of Karachi.
The mausoleum of the Quaid-e-Azam is located in Karachi.
The National Museum of Pakistan, Pakistan Maritime Museum, and the beaches at Clifton and Sandspit are some other landmarks of Karachi.
Lahore is an ancient city on the eastern bank of the River Ravi.
Lahore came under Muslim rule in the 11<font face="GG Superscript">th</font> century.
After independence in 1947, Lahore became the capital of the Punjab province.
Minar-e-Pakistan and the tombs of Jahangir and Nur Jehan are located in Lahore.
Rawalpindi is a major city on the Grand Trunk Road between Peshawar and Lahore.
Rawalpindi is one of the oldest settlements along the Khyber-Peshawar-Lahore route.
Rawalpindi is now the headquarters of the Pakistan Armed Forces.
Rawalpindi is also an important trading centre with a population of over 3 million.
Peshawar is the capital of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa.
Peshawar is the gateway between Central Asia and the subcontinent.
The word 'Quetta' comes from a Pushto word Kwatta which means 'fort'.
Quetta is situated at a height of 1700 metres.
Quetta is situated at a height of 1700 metres.
Quetta serves as an important road junction with routes leading into Afghanistan and Iran.

Quetta is the capital of Balochistan.
